creator: sw@empolis.co.uk
text:
There does not appear to be a way of reproducing the following command in Ant:

jar -t myapp.jar

The output of this command would be a Table of Contents for the jar file. If
there is a way please accept my apologies for wasting your time - but please
bear in mind that it is not clear from the online documentation that there is a
way to do this.

Thanks
Stuart

creator: jan@materne.de
text:
Of course you can use the <exec> task for that. But i wonder what you want to 
do with a jar listing. 

Or do you want to create the listing file? Then <jar index="true"/> would help.

creator: sw@empolis.co.uk
text:
The idea of listing a table of contents for an existing jar file is just to 
verify the contents. ie that the jar file contains what the developer intended.
It was my expectation that i would be able to build a jar with ant, and then 
list the contents of the jar to confirm that it contains the expected files.

I know this could be achieved using exec, but I thought I'd raise it because it 
would be nice for the <jar> attributes to map directly onto the available jar 
options.

Just to confirm - this functionality has nothing to do with indexing the jar 
(in my mind at least).

Thanks
Stuart

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text:
<jar> doesn't use jar, it really only creates jar files using Ant's very own
zip library.  It tries to emulate quite a few of jar's features, but not all
of them.

Currently <exec> is the way to go for you.

hmm... even though this is closed, don't forget:

<pathconvert (...attrs)>
  <path><zipfileset src="foo.jar" /></path>
</pathconvert>

You could even wrap it up in a <jart> macrodef if you really wanted to... so
IMHO this bug is actually WORKSFORME.
